This was a good test - and it's interesting because the answers can be used in actual algebra class - but I'd be worried about how much of the answers are right if I had to guess in a test that could be passed as a grade 1 math course.

If a number is equal to more than one other number, it's called a sum.

If a pair of numbers are equal to more than one another, they're equal to more than one sum.

If two numbers are equal, there's a term called the "conjugate".

If three different numbers are equal to each other, they're all equal to each other. There's no conjunctive.

For any two numbers in a multi-digit series, there's a conjunctive if there's only one number between the points of the series.

For each "number" in a two-digit series, there is "tens" of a number "in a" series. There's "thousands" of a number in a "fraction" series. There's also "centuries". See the second page for the list of conjunctive numbers.
Note that this is not the same as taking a "tens" or a "thousands" of that "number" in another number series. For example,

Suppose you want to get the number of "tens" in a "centuries" series using this method of asking the right questions:

Suppose you have two sets, Set A and Set B. They are numbered from one to n on a number wheel. Find the value n for Set A.

Suppose you are given two sets and a number wheel. You cannot pick a sequence of numbers off the wheel and use those numbers to make a series. What is the sequence of numbers you can pick?

The conjunctive series is the product between two sums of two numbers, in a series of sums. As the conjunctive gets longer and longer, it gets harder for the conjunctive and long series to work together to produce something new.

Comments:

What did you see?

In the pictures:

The "two men" in the picture are two completely different people. The first one is the man in the front of the picture. The second man has a mustache, is dressed up like a doctor, and has a white coat on.

I agree with T.S. and the poster that said "The question makes no sense." The question that your teacher gave the students only had five correct answers. It made no sense.

"What is the difference between the men in the picture?"

This question is dumb. It makes no sense. The man in the picture is the front of the picture and is wearing a white hat, white coat, and tie.

"If you have two,... you have none."

Yes, they do not. But you have a choice in the "two." But in the picture, you cannot see a difference.

"That is a great question."

It is not a very good question. We don't see a difference in the persons in the picture, only you can see that they are different.

"That looks just about right."

That is all that you have to see to know that they are different. (Which is the same thing that a person in the picture can see.)

"You can see only what is right in front of you."

This statement is not true. You can see the differences between the men in the front of the photo. Only you can see two of them, and that doesn't matter.

Input: Dennison was a successful doctor in his day and his patients all made do with his budget.  Then one day, he was in his office working on a medical issue when he came across an article about how much each type of food cost when it was going to a doctor's office.  He then went through his paper files looking for receipts on foods that he had charged his patients.  He found that at least 80% of every dollar that a patient had paid was for food in some form.  Dennison decided to check up on this information to see if he could be less wasteful.  He then went to the hospital on the 10th anniversary of the article and found out that the costs per patient were almost exactly double what it had been in his day.  Dennison then set a goal to find out how much the same food would cost to buy for each year in his day by putting a value on every food bill and comparing the cost of the present food bills to the cost of their previous bills.  After 5 years, Dennison realized that his bill was a staggering $50 billion dollars, or 7.5% of their annual revenue.  Dennison set a goal for himself to get to a level where his total was just 1/30th of his annual revenue.  Denny set a goal of $1.00 to spend on a bill and after several years of saving 5 cents a day, Denny eventually saved enough that he could afford his food bill.  He went from spending more on food bills himself to receiving 6% of his annual budget as the food bill.  After several more years, Denny was able to reduce the food bill by a further 1/4.  With the new food bill of $300,000 a month, Dennison was able to eliminate all his extra costs, save a lot of extra money, provide better service, and to have a healthier office.  He went from operating at the loss of $800,000 dollars to operating at $7.3 million dollars.  After 5 years of this, Dennison realized a goal that he would like to reach, and he was able to do it by reaching 40% of his annual revenue.
Output: 12 out of 10

The sales man says he can't afford it so he can't take the cash. They then agree on a time. Two hours later, the sales rep comes into the office, grabs a stack of $20 bills, and hands them to the salesman. The sales man puts the bills into his pocket with the bill. The sales rep asks how much profit the salesman made that day. The salesman puts in the $2.00 commission on all sales and says he earned $50.00 and gave some back to the dealer. The sales rep then asks if the salesman can have $20.00. He says he doesn't have change and would like to hold onto the bill. The sales man hands him the bill and the sales rep runs out of the office. 5 minutes later, the salesman returns, retrieves the $20.00 bill, and hands it back to the sales rep. The sales rep asks what is going on. The salesman says he just ran out of cash and couldn't pay the commission. The sales rep tells them that he doesn't give out commissions so he doesn't need them. The salesman then takes out the $10.00 from his wallet and hands it to the sales rep. He has asked the salesman to put the $20.00 back on the bill. Input:
In the first week of the school year, when the classes have been merged into high school grades, the school receives a letter from the school board detailing the changes and how they are being evaluated.  A letter is distributed to every teacher and includes the following comments:      * "New students will be grouped together into two groups. Each first year student will be in the class of their same grade level and they will share materials and use the same subjects.  Second year students will be placed in classes similar to their grade levels.  For the first semester, teachers will use this time to reflect and work on individual lessons, develop lesson plans, and communicate with students in a more meaningful, open, and personal way."
       "Teachers will also be assigned the same students they have each taught for the past 3 years.  The focus will be to help foster relationships and develop close relationships with the individual students.  As a result of the changes this year, each teacher will receive a new assignment, and therefore, will be reevaluated based on their own evaluations.  "
    The school board then proceeds to evaluate the effectiveness of the "new year" teacher evaluations in terms not of content knowledge or knowledge of students, but of relationships with teachers.  They ask the following questions:     * Are you getting your students to communicate clearly and with authority?     * Do you have good relationships with your students and are you a good listener?      Are their expectations appropriate?     Do you communicate and share ideas with students in a way that helps students move forward in their learning?     The only answer teachers receive is "no".  There is no mention of "relationships". The only reason teachers are evaluated for content knowledge is not because of content knowledge, but because they have to "catch up".
    The next step is a yearly evaluation. The following comments are asked for in the "evaluations":      Why do you teach the new year curricula?     Why are you using new teacher lesson plans?     What changes will be made in the curriculum this year?     How will you use assessment to help us develop next year's curriculum?     Are you willing to meet with students to discuss individual lesson plans?   Is there feedback and positive interaction going on between students

John is then told that he will be getting ice cream cones, but only one. In addition to that, he will be getting a cookie from the same counter. The next store is also full of ice cream cones and Bob has a cookie. Finally he is asked to choose one of two other ice cream cones. John chooses the one with the frosting and eats it. Bob then has the option to choose between the other ice cream cones or a cookie. He chooses the cookie.  John then asks the manager if he would mind moving the counter from where they are standing. He is then told that moving it would be impossible. John tells him that he does not care and moves the bench to the side of the counter. Next, the manager tells John he has about 2 minutes to pick out a cookie from the remaining ice cream cones and tells him that he needs to choose very quickly because the remaining 3 ice cream cones were sold out.  John thinks the next thing the manager could have asked him to do is to ask him to clean the counter or wash his hands. He doesn’t bother to do that though because he decided to eat the cookie straight up.  As they are making their way to the counter, John tells him that it is “good to be Mr. Nice Guy”. If he puts the tension on 1,000 times more than he would, for example, if he wanted the string to spin ten times more, then he doubles the tension to 1000 times.  If he decides that the amount of tension he is using is just too low, then he tries ten times the tension.  The more weight he spreads over the string, of course the harder it falls to the floor.  He might decide to increase the tension ten times.  If he finds out that the string is really not spinning at all, then he makes another increase by ten times more.  If he finds that the string is spinning so fast that he can no longer even see it, then he makes a further increase in tension ten times as much.  After increasing ten times in the process, he decides that he needs to get the string on the floor as quickly as possible.  He tries one hundred times the tension then, and another ten times.  Finally after trying on one hundred times, he is able to put his finger on the string that he is using to try spinning, and as the weight increases on that string, it is able to actually spin without the aid of any other string.  When he uses that string that is spinning, he has only one choice:  he must increase the tension ten times again.  If he does that until he gets the desired results, then he does not have to go in for any more increments in the tension.  If he does not get the desired results he must try to reduce the tension ten times, but he could not increase it much beyond that. Thanksgiving is one of my favorite holiday. The decorations and lights are sparkling, and the turkeys are singing. But one of my absolute favorite holiday traditions is the Thanksgiving dinner! SOCIAL EDUCATION SOCIAL EDUCATION SOCIETY SOCIETY

SOCIAL AND THE SOCIALISTS

Socialists
Socialists and revolutionaries are engaged in social struggle
because they feel that their ideas can have an influence on both the
state and the class, but to be influential they need more means than the
state offers in fighting oppression. Since the government
lack of means means that most of the people do not get the chance of
facing the oppression, socialists take to the streets.

SOCIALISM

Socialism is to the working class what Communism is to the proletariat.
Socialism is the belief that the working class has a right to an autonomous
classless state.

Socialism is a method of organizing the working class. In reality, it is the organization of the working class by its leaders or its trade union organization. Unlike Communists, Communists are not activists and have little influence outside of the Communist Party and the Red Army. Socialists work with and for the working class.

Social democracy is very broad and includes a variety of policies but is primarily concerned with programs which assist the needs of the oppressed; education, health care, housing and job creation. The term is used to refer to governments, political parties, social welfare organizations and even individual countries with a strong democracy.

Social democratic policies are more focused on the needs of the working class and may not be as developed or as developed as communism and social reformism.

Social democracy was established as a result of the struggles of the oppressed nations of the 20th century to maintain their national identity and their unity. This was achieved through organizations such as the United Nations, the League of Nations and its successor institutions, the European Economic Community and the International Monetary Fund, etc.

After World War Two, social democratic governments around the world gained power as they offered greater equality to the oppressed. Socialism and social democracy have been considered complementary since both rely on the same goals.

Socialism cannot be considered a form of government. It is a plan by the working class to unite and organize itself to gain a greater share of the profits and material goods. A form of socialism would be the government of the working class itself.

Communism can be seen as a form of socialism. Both share the main goal of ending the oppression of the proletariat by the class ruled government. Communist governments, while

input: The first thing that comes to mind when you hear the words "art” and “music” is probably images of a symphony-filled field where music comes out of a horn and a musician uses a guitar to play the music in the field. Art is “anything produced for the purpose of creating a work of art as recognized by international organizations and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.” “Music” has been defined a “musical form which is essentially the art of speech” (1). The word music can also be used in combination with “art.“ In an almost literal sense music is the expression of rhythm and sounds used to form phrases, but as a more general term it could also fit art and art-related. What artists are often called “artists” is an open question, one that has been raised in many different contexts, including popular culture, and art school. Some terms given as examples in popular culture, (“a famous artist”) have not actually meant anything more than the person who is famous, and have been used to describe any sort of creative endeavor. In art school many artists are known by these terms and are therefore called artists, but some of the students are simply known as students, or by other terms such as students of art.

You know when I said that, I told him, 'My money is in my account.  Jack, don't take my money.'  All my money is in my
account.  All my money is right here."  Jack took that as the best response.  He had saved his money.  That was it.  He couldn’t do anything about it.  They were right.  Saving money and putting it in an account is a good thing.  He’d saved the money.  He was proud of himself.  He was

If the average age is 30,000 (the median, which is approximately 30,000) and the average age of a marriage is 50,000, the number of marriages per year becomes 21,000/50,000, for an average of 20,000 per year.   If the average age of marriage is 40,000 (which is the average, i.e. 29,000 - 40,000) then the above average should be 21,000/20,000  instead, it is 21,000/29,000, for an increase of 28.6 %.  This is very different from what happens with the median age.  The median marriage age grows from 27.3 and decreases as you get older than 30 years.  The following graph shows the trend in median marriage ages in the U.S.  If the graph is increasing, the trend in marriage ages is up, the trend in median marriage age is down, and the median marriage ages are close to each other. So, it would appear that marriage may be improving but it does not improve by 28.6 %, instead it is stable.

The word "plural" can be used if you want to show "a number of." In this case, it will be "the number of goods sold (in a period) in this retail outlet (for a period of)..." As long as the total number of goods sold is exactly the number of goods purchased it should be the same. If the total number of goods purchased was less than the total number sold then one has to have only one product, which is a different word than "plural." In a similar fashion, a quantity sold, or a sale, is the same as "a number of lots sold in this retail outlet for a given period (for a given period). A lot of people are likely to get their Christmas presents from one particular retailer, so a lot of retail outlets will have a lot of Christmas merchandise.

Example: Bill went to an Internet store and purchased the item #17:
$2.55=$2.75
$3.50/$4.25
$4.50/$2.00
$2.50/$3.25
$4/$1.00
$2/$1.00

### Response: B

The word "substantially" can be used when you want to show "one or more" instead of "nearly or exactly." In this case, the word "nearly" is used as the replacement word by "one or more" and "nearly" will be used as the replacement word with "one or more goods" and "nearly." In a similar fashion by using "nearly" it will be assumed that the number of goods sold by "this retail outlet (for a given period) is (nearly) the number of goods purchased."

Example: When a customer places an order with a particular company he receives a delivery confirmation that says:
"Thank you for your order. This is number 1 of 1,000 orders in that category that you have placed. We are estimating that it will be shipped to your address by Friday, December 22, 2017. Please leave us a message or return visit our website to check your status. Thank you."

Input: The top 3 most common forms of divorce are: A : annulment B : separation C : separation D : dissolution
Output: 150

Suggested Answer A: Annulment
Input: Annulment is the process of annulling a marriage. It is a legal procedure that lets the courts determine whether two people meet the legal criteria (matrimonial agreement) necessary to legally marry someone. When a court orders an annulment, it is done so that one of the parties to the marriage is free to marry someone else.
Output: 150
Suggested Answer B: Separation
Input: Separation is when one of the partners of a relationship or marriage decides that the relationship or marriage is not working for them. When the person making this decision wants to end the relationship, the couple goes through a separation process to determine whether an out of court divorce is a viable option. Usually the person who requests that the relationship or marriage be separated is the person who initiated the breakup.
Output: 150

Input: The following is an excerpt from the novel "Fifty Shades Darker."

The movie is a complete rip-off of several other books and movies. Some names are already familiar; The Dark Tower is based on "The Dark Knight" by Christopher Nolan, The Hunger Games is based on "The Hunger Games" by Suzanne Collins, and the Hunger Games: Catching Fire follows "Catching Fire" by Suzanne Collins. There are a few other authors who have also made movies based on their novels, but the majority that have had a movie made are either the Twilight series, the Harry Potter series (although Harry Potter was made in 3 parts) or the Twilight movies. These three series are popular, and the other ones are more popular as well, so it is understandable why they have had movies made.

The Hunger Games movies had mixed reviews among the general public, but still succeeded with the adults who read and watched the books. "Fifty Shades Darkr" came about after the success of the Hunger Games, and has already made a lot of money for the studios, so they are planning to continue the series and make a lot of money. The movie has received mixed reviews and low-quality reviews. The rating for the Hunger Games movies, and then the rating for "Darker", are a success in terms of gross revenue, but in terms of entertainment (including the movies), they do not hold up to the quality of other movies like "Star Wars".

The movie is not a popular series because it does not have much substance to it. The story is repetitive, and everything that happens in the first three movies, the first three acts of the novel also end up in the movie. The movie seems to be very simplistic, and it lacks the development that the book had. At the end of the book, the characters go into a new world that the movie makes seem like "Groundhog Day", where all of the events are the same, but it adds nothing to the books. Overall, if you were to read "Fifty Shades Dark" and not see "Fifty Shades Dark", the book would do nothing to advance the series, but if you're a fan of the series, then this movie is a decent rip-off.

(This is a loan with a variable interest rate; after you make the $6.50/year payment, your interest will rise from 3% to 9%. Also, you have to pay full principal because your loan can only be paid up to 90 days after the loan goes into the default category.) So with a $10,000 principal, you would still pay the same $300 in interest that you would have paid for the initial $10,000 with a $200 minimum payment. In this example, if your loan is paid on time, it is actually better to have an additional small loan to pay the $500 minimum payments. If you are paying on time, you actually have no money, you are just borrowing from yourself. In this example, it would seem that you could go without food, or use all the money you saved for other purposes and live. It is far more important to maintain your credit rating. You should have thought about this before you signed the loan. And you should have taken the loan out of a different account. In this example, your friend should have taken the money out of her account; it would be much more cost efficient and there is no guarantee that she would have access to the same credit line. Therefore, she should not have signed a $10,000 unsecured loan. Also, this is not a good time for her to be borrowing $10,000; therefore, she should have a job. Output: B

David was not better until he was 14. When they did find an active infection, the doctor said that his infection was an upper respiratory infection. They gave him a treatment to keep it active. One day, David was coughing up blood for three days. He began to feel nauseous but continued to treat the fever. Finally he started to feel better and thought that he might not be sick after all but that his cough was not getting better. So they still treated his cough. He then was more nauseous so he felt another dose of medicine. One day when everyone was in school, he came to school coughing and sweating profusely as well. So again the doctor advised them to wait one more week or two before they started antibiotics but they decided to take care of his fever. When at dinner that night, David complained about the pain of his neck and they gave him medicine for that as well. David didn't recover quickly so he took another dose of medicine. When we mentioned that we needed some money for our parents to care for the kids at certain times, David's friends offered to pay for these occasional costs. One of his friends even gave us a free bike. My friends often invited us out and to movies, restaurants, festivals, and parks so that we could see their babies. I still remember the first time we went to a park with two little girls, we walked around in the park for hours and enjoyed the outdoors with our kids. The children of the people who lived in the building often threw birthday parties for us. One birthday party brought a whole bunch of cookies, so we were able to get extra calories from that. I also remember how one day some of the kids threw me a bike. The bike was nice, but I do not remember if it was free or paid for. Over the years my apartment has become less and less of a place of family fun. Some of these friends have moved.
